title: Liberal and Conservative leaders respond to scale-up questions with re-promises
text:
At a Quebec City campaign stop, Justin Trudeau highlighted a proposal for the Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC) to give 2,000 entrepreneurs up to $50,000 in startup capital, and said his Liberals have “done an awful lot over the past four years.” In Toronto, Andrew Scheer said a Conservative government would focus on “tackling the regulatory burden,” and cited the green-patent tax credit in its environmental plan. (The Logic)

Talking point: None of the proposals the leaders cited specifically target scale-ups; some of them—like the Liberals’ BDC funding pilot—are specifically designed to help new or small firms, instead. That’s in keeping with the election campaign so far. All four major parties have promised new restrictions or taxes on foreign tech giants, but none has pledged significant new programs or funding for fast-growing firms. The current Liberal government has retargeted some major business-support organizations—like the Industrial Research Assistance Program and Sustainable Development Technology Canada—onto bigger projects. The Conservative green-patent tax credit addresses the same cleantech IP protection concern as the current government’s patent collective; the party’s environmental plan also includes $250 million for green technology venture capital funds-of-funds, to which the Liberal government allocated $50 million.
